however I think in this case it's it's
Germain um there was a wonderful comment
that a colleague of yours whose name
forgive me I can't remember the very
first time I ever did this class with
you um there were I think only three
people or something it was anyway it was
another composition uh professor and I
was having trouble parsing out what
looked on paper to be a very simple
Melody but it was awkwardly written it
was a uh they were funny intervals and
and strange jumps on unusual syllables
and the student composer it should be
said was becoming annoyed with me for
missing it repeatedly and then her
professor raised his hand and very tly
said
well take an experienced musician in an
awkward line of music and you can't
expect it to be much smoother than that
at first gloss and it was a very telling
comment um and it's incredibly ephemeral
Concept in in that you know what what
does a smooth or logical or organic
melody mean to each of us and it depends
also on what compositional idiom you're
working in you know something like this
that owes so much to the tradition of uh
say German art song or let's say uh
basically art song from the mid mid 19th
century um there are certain standards
of of um excuse me standards isn't the
word I want there are certain uh
convention in the way Melodies will
unfold that we all kind of accept and
listen for and for some reason I I think
it has largely to do with where you're
going harmonically that interval is hard
for me to hear the C to F it's only it's
an open fifth it's the easiest interval
you can possibly sing nonetheless
because harmonically it's heading in a
direction that doesn't necessarily make
that much
sense uh in regard to what has preceded
it it feels a little bit awkward um now
I understand where you're where you're
wanting to wind up and that does make
sense sort of on paper but at the same
time you've embedded us so so deeply in
this new harmonic
area if you really want to get back to
the home key it seems to me that the
song should happen in three episodes one
being the ultimate the uh initial
statement rather in the home key area
then your trip to whatever relative key
area you wish to go and then some sort
of vocal resolution that brings us back
to the home area now again this the this
is I'm talking strictly in terms of that
kind of Convention of 19th century art
song um this whole idea uh of symmetry
which of course you know has been in
existence long before that period but I
think just for the sense
of going back to the home key area you
need to give the singer a little bit
more and not just sort of let the piano
take care of it there is of course I
don't know how much Schuman you've
listened to the art song of of Robert
Schuman obviously right and left he does
this very odd thing for those of you who
have not listened to a lot of Schuman
Shan is famous for writing these
magnificent songs and then tacking on
these seemingly like unrelated postludes
that go on sometimes for a minute
there's a famous song cycle of his where
the last song the singer has just poured
out her heart in this you know terribly
wrenching way you know that her husband
has died in her she will bury herself
you know within her own heart and never
never be revealed again very dark ending
she finishes the song and then he sort
of gives us a little leading chord and
then goes off on this like gorgeous
Little Piano Sonata all by himself and
the singer just sort of stands there and
the first time I saw that I was like oh
thanks thanks a lot that's really handy
so I think it can work in very specific
context I mean I it's hard not to stand
there and feel like you have egg on your
face but unless you parse out the idea
of of the the key that you want to end
up in more thoroughly I say either
elongate your
postlude have it make more of a
statement about what has preceded so it
gives balance at the end of the song to
what has happened at the front end
because the front end is very strong you
have this very emotional I mean it
reminds me a little bit of um Al of of
shat which I'm sure you've listen to uh
where we have a distinct voice of a
character and then a distinct voice of
uh a narrator so you've given us this
nice thing but then we're sort of
missing the day new mall sort of missing
the last step now obviously there's no
more text in the poem you're all fresh
out but I guess uh that's the one thing
that is sort of missing to me an overall
sense of balance uh to the song in terms
of how it sings in terms of how it feels
in the voice it's very nicely written in
terms of uh vocal line um a typical trap
that young composers often fall into
including ones who really should know
better because they're earning their
money being composers um is to either be
far too conservative with the voice and
just sort of out of out of fear of of
demanding too much or just going
completely off the deep end and having
you know making demands of this of the
singer that are just not vocally
appropriate for the person's uh fa or
voice cat organization uh and you've
done a good job of sort of having one
foot in each Camp having the bulk of the
melody sitting in a very comfortable
sort of middle range and allowing it to
Arc up and down
um to make certain dramatic statements
which I think is really clever um and
difficult to do as well so cros to you
for
that um Daniel you forgive me if i n on
for a couple seconds longer um with
regard to the score itself there's one
particularly strange thing and Peter you
need to put in your two cents here but
it's measure 20 it's a very awkward way
of notating that Rhythm if that's indeed
the Rhythm that you
intended it comes out is the night was
dark no father was there it was kind of
a if I were
to recite it with a rhythm that made the
most sense to me with in context of the
speech I would have probably said the
night was dark no father was there in
other words back the whole thing up by
an E
note the way it's written there in uh in
68 we're looking for certain visual
groupings on the page and to give us you
know the qu note makes sense I mean it's
nothing fancy but what trips up the eye
is the dotted e tied to the 16th tied to
the two additional eights if you see
what I mean that's a that looks odd on
the page and it makes if we're thinking
in 68 we're not necessarily going to
parse that out as a sudden feel of 34
because that's not a 34 pulse is not
something that we're feeling uniformly
throughout this section you see what I'm
talking about I'm not sure I'm
articulating it as clearly as as a
composer would but um I say either if
you want to stick to that Rhythm then
see if you can find a different way of
notating it with Tide notes tide notes
seem fussy and weird but actually
visually they can make the language much
clearer to the eye when looking at
it my only suggestion uh in my
own uh what am I trying to
say in support of my other suggestion
which is shifting up slightly like
moving it back by an eighth note would
be to give a truer sense of the shape of
the text this comes out feel like no
father was there I'm not sure if you
mean no father was there or no father
was there you need to make up your mind
which is the important word in there
because the way you said it it's it's it
falls in neither Camp you
see I'm trying to think if I had any
other ideas with regard to the score I
didn't Daniel would you please feel
through that I'll say a couple of things
um first that I appreciate a lot of the
articulation that you've given this
piano part um and but one one difficult
thing about this piece is when there are
different articulations in each hand and
it's
something that certainly as a Pianist
you come across but but it's always a
very uh specific thing that a composer
is going for when when a Pianist is
asked to do such separate articulations
in the hands um and even I don't know if
you noticed in 24 I think the second
time we did it I played the right hand
Legato and I played the left hand
staccato I you know I revers the
articulations um and I guess I'm only
mentioning this to
say be be careful when you do that um
because it it makes such a strong
impression on me to see that on the page
um but I agree that the
end feels it feels a little lopsided in
favor of of the front of the piece and
that if if you do get a chance to expand
on the end I was I love measure eight
when that Chola Rhythm comes in uh in my
part this
[Music]
and I was kind of waiting for that to
come back at the end um and I know you
don't have the same text to work with
but it's such a memorable moment that if
that kind of gesture were to come back
at the end it would give us that sense
of return and solidifying you know the
home key and all of
that no very very nice part to play I
wanted to extract
briefly on the points Danel made about
articulation which are really really
really well put one thing that I find I
have found I should say uh frequently is
often what makes differences in
articulation really work or what
gives tension to a piece is if the
entire piano part has one texture and
the voice is asked to use a different
texture um I can think of aund different
examples um of course now I can't oh
there there's a a piece probably one of
many called of
shat where the piano is really imitating
the plucking of a mandolin it's
like and the voice has this sort of
fabulous sort of honeyed soaring
gorgeous thing but it's the contrast
between you know if the piano was
all and the voice was doing that it
would sound like a big muddy mess but
because it's
juxtaposed dry against wet pretty good
way of putting it um somehow it just
makes the song Come to Life it makes it
so romantic and so evocative suddenly
you hear precisely what is intended
you've got such a good a sense of the
sort of like
brooding uh picture that the poem uh
delineates I think that you can work
using articulation specifically between
the voice partner piano part um or
Dynamics or whatever it may be to
heighten that and make it more specific
I also thought of one other thing that I
wanted to mention which
is uh and again this has a lot to do
with the convention of 19th century song
which this which your composition seems
to owe uh a good deal to and that is a a
not a terribly strong feeling of cadence
at the end and I'm not saying that it
has to be that way of course it doesn't
it's always one's individual choice but
if you're working within this harmonic
language uh unless you're going to do
something that
is very specifically moving away from
that tradition in other words paying uh
tribute to that tradition of of vocal
and piano writing yet putting your own
impr prematur on it I think it needs to
be more specific and clearly articulated
then sort of a a Cadence that kind of
hints at something a little bit more
abstract but doesn't really deliver bit
of goods so again it all gets back to
the idea of giving the piece more
balance giving it a little something on
the end to weigh it down if that makes
sense um for the piano part purposely
didn't want to have strong Cadence
because I wanted to go back to text
painting for the vapor flu um
part but yeah I agree I should expand
more upon if that's the intent then
there's a good deal more you can do to
help push your pianist in that Direction
and again you could feel free to
interrup me but I would suggest marking
your ritardando earlier and marking
Dynamics for sure uh with actual words
or like uh morendo or
uh I don't know just find find find the
right combination of of words and
diacritical markings to indicate that
you're looking for a very specific sort
of ephemeral Vanishing vaporous effect
because here looking at it it looks like
you want the same in all four measures
and a little bit of slowing down and a
little bit quiet in the last measure
when in fact the effect you're going for
will demand a lot
more uh a lot more of something of De
Crescendo or lightness of touch or more
pedal or less pedal or something but
whatever it is don't be afraid to be
specific Daniel made a great comment at
the beginning which is that a
well-marked piece I mean it may seem
fiddly and fussy to go in you know
finale or whatever put in all those
stupid Within These pedal articulations
we love that kind of thing that's that's
where we we sort of live and die as
performers I mean I love having you know
a piece by I know name name your
favorite 17th Century composer you know
where there are no diacritical markings
at all because you know you get to make
up your own mind about things but what I
particularly love is a composer like
Benjamin Brittain where everything was
incredibly specific and he was Notorious
for being so dactic and really
irritating with his publisher be like he
you left the rest out throw them away
print it again so the more specific you
can be the stronger impression you give
us of what you intend so in other words
if there aren't enough di critical
markings it seems to us like you have it
made up your mind and yet you're telling
me that you have a very specific thing
in mind so let that be expressed on the
page Peter what would you like to do
shall we move on yeah all right good
that's very beautiful Stephanie nice job
